a/v?
HR always offers great quality uploads! So this one is quality as well!

Quality is subjective.  The best possible picture and sound is the bluray disk.  You will see lots of people write 10/10 on things I would consider to be 2/10.  Rarely do I think these are 10/10.  More realistic average is like 8.5/10.  It depends on material and source.  You will always find flaws if you look hard enough.  In general though if you are looking that hard then you are probably not watching the movie.  Some releases I just think are god awful because they use horrible sharpening enhancers to downplay that their bitrate is very low.

If you are follower just click the download button and go back to whatever you were doing.  You should know by now there isn't any other viable alternative.

If you aren't following maybe you should be.

hsn_kmr:  I can't answer all of your questions, but I'll try to answer some.
1)  Release dates of dvd's and blu-rays are different from region to region, country to country.  While a movie may not be available to buy in say the United States, it may be available to purchase many weeks sooner in other counties.  There are also different answers for this, for example, someone who works at a store that rents movies is often able to take home and watch them a week or more before the release date.
4) 1080p refers to a resolution 1920 pixels by 1080 pixels with progressive scan (as opposed to 1080i where the "i" would indicate interlaced.)  When something is 1920x800, it simply means that the black bars above and below the picture that are included on the blu-ray, or whatever, are trimmed from the copy.  In that example, it is taking 280 lines of black bar off the picture.  It is still 1080p picture, just without the "empty" space.
As for your 5th question, which torrents you should download just depends on what you want to use them for.  In HR's case, they are specifically geared toward "direct playback on Apple TV, iPhone, iPad, iPod, PS3, WDTV, Xbox360, Popcorn Hour, and VLC."  If you plan to play the movie on one of those devices, HR is the way to go.  If you are using a device with HD playback, go for the 720p's, if it's like an iPod, or older iPod touch or iPhone then you want the portable version.

fyi the description stuff effects retail videos from the iTunes store.  If the media was in your itunes prior then the descriptions will show up.  If you remove item from itunes, close itunes, relaunch itunes, re-add media the description will no longer show up.  it effects retail assets from the iTunes store as well.
